name: Number of regions in the arrangement of hyperplanes corresponding to the nonzero differences of two permutations of order n.
comment: The number of distinct hyperplanes is given by A381243.
program: (Sage) def a381244(n): return HyperplaneArrangements(QQ,tuple(f'x{i}' for i in range(n)))([[list(r),0] for p in Permutations(n) for r in Permutations([p[i]-i-1 for i in range(n)]) if vector(r)>0]).n_regions()
author: _Max Alekseyev_, Feb 17 2025

name: Number of hyperplanes defined by the nonzero differences of two permutations of order n.
comment: Each of A175176(n) - 1 nonzero differences between two permutations (viewed as a vectors) defines a hyperplane in n-dimensional space, some of which coincide. a(n) gives the number of pairwise distinct hyperplanes among them.
author: _Max Alekseyev_, Feb 17 2025

name: Number of vector differences between two permutations of order n, up to multiplication by nonzero rational numbers and permutations of the components.
comment: Nonzero difference vectors are associated with their images in the projective space, and in addition we do not distinguish vectors that can be permuted one into the other. In the affine space, their number (including zero vector) is given by A019589, implying that a(n) <= A019589(n). Nonzero difference vectors in the projective space are counted by A381243.
example: For n = 3, there are A019589(3) = 5 difference vectors up to permutation of components: (-2, 0, 2), (-2, 1, 1), (-1, -1, 2), (-1, 0, 1), and (0, 0, 0). However, (-2, 0, 2) and (-1, 0, 1) are the same up to a factor 2, and (-2, 1, 1) and (-1, -1, 2) are the same up to negation and reversing the order. Hence, a(3) = 3.
author: _Max Alekseyev_, Feb 20 2025
